snp2.12:343: “We askAll three editions use the pluralpucchāma, butTh 1272has the singularpucchāmi.the teacher of perfect wisdom,the cutter-off of doubts in this very life:a bhikkhu passed away at Aggāḷava,one well known, famous, inwardly quenched. (1)
snp2.12:344: “Nigrodhakappa was his name,which you, Blessed One, gave to the brahmin.Energetic, he lived intent on release,paying homage to you, the one who shows the durable. (2)
snp2.12:345: “O Sakya, we too all wish to knowabout that disciple, O universal eye.Fully attentive, our ears are ready to hear;you are our teacher; you are unsurpassed. (3)
snp2.12:346: “Cut off our doubt! Tell me this:announce he attained nibbāna, you of broad wisdom.Speak up in our midst, O universal eye,like thousand-eyed Sakka among the devas. (4)
snp2.12:347: “Whatever knots are here, paths of delusion,factions of ignorance, bases of doubt, [61]on reaching the Tathāgata, they no longer exist;for he is the supreme eye for humans. (5)
snp2.12:348: “If no man would ever dispel the defilementsas a wind might dispel a mass of clouds,the entire world would be enshrouded, utter darkness,and even brilliant men would not shine. (6)
snp2.12:349: “But wise men are makers of light.I consider you, O hero,I read withBevīra, as againstCeandEedhīra. The gloss inPj II,padhānaviriyasamannāgata, indicates thatvīrawas the reading available to the commentator.to be such a one.Knowing, we come to one endowed with insight:in the assemblies, disclose to us [the fate of] Kappa. (7)
snp2.12:350: “Quickly send forth your lovely voice, O lovely one!WithBe, I would insert a space, readingvaggu vagguṃ, takingvagguas a vocative andvagguṃin apposition togiraṃ.Like a goose that has stretched out, gently honkwith your rounded voice, well-modulated.We are all upright: let us hear you! (8)
snp2.12:351: “He has abandoned birth and death entirely;having pressed the pure one, I will make him speak the Dhamma.For worldlings cannot act on their wishes,but for the tathāgatas, action is based on comprehension. (9)
snp2.12:352: “This excellent declaration of yourshas been accepted [as coming] from one of upright wisdom.This last reverential salutation is offered.Knowing, do not delude us, you of perfect wisdom. (10)
snp2.12:353: “Having understood the noble Dhamma from top to bottom,knowing, do not delude us, O one of perfect energy. [62]As one afflicted by heat in summer longs for water,I long for your word: so pour down the sound!I read withBeandCesutaṃ pavassa, as againstEesutassavassa.(11)
snp2.12:354: “Was the beneficial spiritual lifethat Kappāyana led not lived in vain by him?Did he attain nibbāna or did a residue remain?Let us hear just how he was liberated.” (12)
snp2.12:355: “He cut off craving here for name-and-form,”“the stream of the Dark One that had long lay dormant.He crossed over birth and death entirely.”Thus spoke the Blessed One, chief of the five. (13)
snp2.12:356: “Having heard your word,I am pleased, O best of rishis.Indeed, my question was not in vain;the brahmin did not deceive me. (14)
snp2.12:357: “The Buddha’s disciple was onewho acted in accordance with what he said.He cut through the net of Death,extended tightly by the Deceiver. (15)
snp2.12:358: “Kappiya, O Blessed One,saw the origin of clinging.Kappāyana, indeed, overcamethe domain of Death so hard to cross.” (16) [63]
